channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Associate of Russian Arms Dealer Is Convicted in New York
item.description: Richard A. Chichakli, a dual American and Syrian citizen, was convicted Friday of conspiring with the Russian arms trafficker Viktor Bout.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Nuclear Talks Interrupted
item.description: Iranian diplomats interrupted nuclear talks after the United States announced an expanded list of companies and individuals whose trading activities it would try to block for evading sanctions against Iran.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Vaccine Teams Attacked
item.description: Attacks on polio teams in northwest Pakistan on Friday killed a polio worker and two police officers assigned to protect one of the teams, the police and a government official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Blast Kills 21 Coal Miners
item.description: A blast at a coal mine in China’s far-west Xinjiang region killed 21 people on Friday, the state news agency Xinhua said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Unicef Urges Aid for Syria’s Shattered School System
item.description: Among the 4.8 million Syrian children of school age, some 2.2 million who are still in the country are no longer in school, a report says.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Among the 4.8 million Syrian children of school age, some 2.2 million who are still in the country are no longer in school, joining at least half a million — and probably many more — child refugees in neighboring countries, the United Nations Children’s Fund said in released on Friday.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Karzai Impersonator Finds Fame and Misfortune
item.description: A young man named Zabiullah sounds exactly like the Afghan president, but that is where the similarities end.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I think he is exactly like me. Of course, I’ve never met him. But we both have mercurial personalities.”

item.title: For Syrian Refugees Short of Food and Clean Water, Snow Is an Added Challenge
item.description: Families huddled together to try to ward off the cold, as a stormy cold wave hit the Mideast.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A camp in the Bekaa Valley in Lebanon on Friday; more than 100,000 children live in temporary shelters in Lebanon.

item.title: African Crisis Is Tougher Than France Expected
item.description: The scale of the humanitarian needs and the growing sectarian animosity in the Central African Republic threaten to overwhelm France’s goal of quickly restoring order.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Christians in a camp for internally displaced people on Friday in the airport in Bangui, capital of the Central African Republic.

item.title: Land Disputes Slow Recovery in Philippines
item.description: Squatters have long been able to settle on others’ land, but after Typhoon Haiyan some landowners have thwarted rebuilding efforts.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Three Photographers Reflect on Typhoon Haiyan
item.description: More than a month after Hayian ended 6,000 lives, the Philippine people are still recovering. In these videos, New York Times photographers recount their experiences covering the disaster.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: News Analysis: Grasping for Clues in North Korean Execution
item.description: The execution of Kim Jong-un’s uncle could signal a fight over the direction of North Korea while sowing concern about the stability of the country.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Jang Song-thaek in Beijing in 2012. North Korea’s state-run news agency said he was killed after being convicted of treason.

item.title: South Africa Looks Into Claims of Interpreter’s Criminal Past
item.description: The South African authorities said they were aware of news media reports that Thamsanqa Jantjie had been accused of murder in 2003.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN ELIGON

item.title: U.N. Chief Responds to Syria Report
item.description: The United Nations secretary general on Friday said that those who used chemical weapons in Syria should be brought to justice.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: The Lede: With Their Own Images, South Africans Remember Mandela
item.description: During the 10-day period of mourning in South Africa for Nelson Mandela, many people, including readers, documented their experiences in photos and on social media.
item.dc:creator: By SHREEYA SINHA and JENNIFER PRESTON
item.media:description: South Africans paid their respects in Cape Town, where Nelson Mandela had made his first public speech after nearly three decades in prison.

item.title: To Lower Tariffs, Vietnam Pushes for Easing Trade Rules
item.description: Vietnam helps supply much of the apparel worn in the Western world, and negotiations with Europe are being watched with especially close care.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM and ETHAN TUAN
item.media:credit: Aaron Joel Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Screens for printing various "Made in Vietnam" stamps at a factory in Vietnam's Binh Duong province. For goods coming into the European Union from Vietnam, the rules of origin can add up to substantial sums of money.

item.title: The Lede: American Who Killed for Iran’s Revolution in 1980 Resurfaces in C.I.A. Spy Drama
item.description: The C.I.A. contractor who disappeared during a 2007 trip to Iran had traveled there to meet with a man whose life story could provide Hollywood screenwriters with material for a sequel to “Argo.”
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: British Wine Benefits as the Climate Changes
item.description: By midcentury, Britain could become one of the world’s big wine producers, as warmer weather moves the limits of viticulture ever farther north.
item.dc:creator: By GEORGI KANTCHEV
item.media:credit: Warrick Page for The New York Times
item.media:description: Local tourists sampling wine at Denbies Wine Estate, one of Britain’s largest wine producers.

item.title: Snow in Mideast Snarls Kerry’s Shuttle Diplomacy
item.description: The worst winter storm to hit Jerusalem since the 1950s disrupted life in the region and threw a new obstacle into Secretary of State John Kerry’s peace efforts in the region.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: A Ukrainian Uprising Fueled by Outrage (and Salted Pork Fat)
item.description: Heaping bowls of buckwheat, steaming helpings of borscht and other meaty and fatty fare have been sustaining the pro-European demonstrators in Kiev.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: In Ukraine, Feeding the Protest
item.description: As protests continue in Kiev's Independence Square, an army of volunteers brings food and drink to nourish the thousands who remain in the snow and cold.

item.title: Paul Simon on Mandela’s Role in ‘Graceland’
item.description: Paul Simon recalls how the spirit of Nelson Mandela infused the music of “Graceland” and his tours with South African musicians.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL SIMON
item.media:description: Nelson Mandela and Paul Simon in 1992.

item.title: Energy Secretary Calls Oil Export Ban Dated
item.description: Ernest Moniz, the energy secretary, says it is time to reconsider an export ban that stemmed from the oil embargoes of the 1970s.
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.dc:creator: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: Pakistan’s Chief Justice Leaves a Mixed Legacy
item.description: As Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry steps down as chief justice this week, his fight against Pakistan’s military rulers looms large in his legacy — as does his failure to reform a weak legal system.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of suspected criminals on their way to court in Islamabad.

item.title: 25 Prisoners Flee Baghdad Jail
item.description: The authorities questioned whether guards had helped the prisoners, who were facing terrorism charges, escape.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Mexico’s Oil May Be Opened to Outsiders
item.description: Ciudad del Carmen, a hub of the Mexican oil industry, has boomed since large reserves were discovered in the 1970s.
